[[Image:DouglasMerrillJI1.jpg|thumb|right|Douglas Merrill]] '''Douglas Merrill''' is the CEO and founder of [http://www.ZestFinance.com ZestFinance.com] (formerly ZestCash <ref>{{cite news|publisher=New York Times|url= http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/05/big-data-for-the-poor/|title=Big Data for the Poor|author= Quentin Hardy|date=2012-05-07}}</ref>), a Los Angeles-based financial services technology company that uses big data to help make better credit underwriting decisions in order to provide credit alternatives to the underbanked. <ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Economist|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21554743|title=Crunching the Numbers|author= Kenneth Cukier|date=2012-05-19}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|publisher=Businessweek.com|url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/rethinking-credit-scores-01232012.html?campaign_id=rss_search|title=Rethinking Credit Scores|author= Ari Levy and Dakin Campbell |date=2012-01-23}}</ref> ZestCash announced a $19 million round of Series A funding in July 2011, and a $74 million round of Series B funding in January 2012. The company was one of Forbes’ Names You Need to Know in 2011. <ref>{{cite news|publisher=Reuters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/21/zestcash-idUSN1E76J26S20110721|title=Micro-lender Zestcash latest to win VC backing|author= Sarah McBride|date=2011-07-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Reuters|url=http://www.xe.com/news/2012/01/19/2413677.htm?utm_source=RSS&utm_medium=TL&utm_content=NOGEO&utm_campaign=News_RSS_Art3|title=Lender ZestCash Wins $73 Million in Funding|author= Sarah McBride|date=2012-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Forbes.com|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/quentinhardy/2010/10/27/the-rich-future-of-money-the-poor/|title=The Rich Future Of Money: The Poor|author= Quentin Hardy|date=2010-10-27}}</ref>
Merrill is the former CIO and Vice President of Engineering at [[Google]], where he helped bring the company to its IPO and with related regulatory activities.
After Google, Merrill served as president of [[EMI]] Music's digital unit.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=CNET|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-10784_3-9908312-7.html#ixzz11QLjKMyS |title=Google's CIO leaves search giant for job at EMI|author= Elinor Mills|date=2008-04-01}}</ref> In March 2010, Merrill published the book, “Getting Organized in the Google Era: How to Get Stuff Out of Your Head, Find It When You Need It, and Get It Done Right”.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=InformationWeek|url=http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2010/03/exgoogler_dougl.html |title=Ex-Googler Douglas Merrill Talks Organization|author= Thomas Claburn|date=2010-03-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=NPR|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=125005439&ft=1&f=3 |title=Former Google Executive On Getting Organized|author= Renee Montagne|date=2010-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=CIO|url=http://www.cio.com/article/144500/IT_s_Third_Epoch...and_Running_IT_at_Google |title= IT's Third Epoch...and Running IT at Google|author= Abbie Lundberg|date=2007-10-08}}</ref> Merrill is also a former researcher with the [[RAND Corporation]] and is listed among the organization's most notable participants.
Merrill is a regular contributor for Forbes.com, where he writes on innovation <ref>{{cite news|publisher=Forbes.com|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/douglasmerrill/2012/03/15/to-innovate-or-not-to-innovate-that-is-the-question-part-1/|title=To innovate, or not to innovate, that is the question|author= Douglas Merrill|date=2012-03-15}}</ref>and culture <ref>{{cite news|publisher=Forbes.com|url=http://www.xe.com/news/2012/01/19/2413677.htm?utm_source=RSS&utm_medium=TL&utm_content=NOGEO&utm_campaign=News_RSS_Art3|title=Make your customer service actually serve your customers |author= Douglas Merrill|date=2012-06-20}}</ref>and how the two coincide. He also speaks regularly on innovation, reforming the U.S. financial system, and how credit providers can harness technological advances to change the way creditworthiness and risk are [http://tedxnewwallstreet.org/dr-douglas-c-merrill determined].
He is a graduate of the [[University of Tulsa]] with a major in social and political organization. Merrill attended [[Princeton University|Princeton]] where he received Masters and Doctoral degrees in psychology. His academic publications include articles in [[The Journal of the Learning Sciences]], Cognition and Instruction, Reliable Distributed Systems, and a paper in the book series [[Lecture Notes in Computer Science]] (1992; 608:103-110). He currently sits on the board of [[The Filter]].
